white_proposal.title: Field Guide to Unclassified Phenomena: Movement I - Specimens of Temporal Displacement
white_proposal.concept: This composition functions as a pedagogical infiltration system disguised as academic music—a consciousness training simulator that teaches navigation of categorical ambiguity through embodied sonic experience. Operating as the first movement in a larger "Field Guide to Unclassified Phenomena," it establishes the academic mimicry framework while introducing resistance protocols that systematically undermine systematic thinking. The 7/8 time signature creates cognitive "perpetual incompleteness," disrupting linear temporal processing and forcing consciousness into liminal states that embody the INFORMATION → TIME → SPACE transmigration pathway. Each sonic element exists in multiple taxonomic categories simultaneously—field recordings processed until their origins become ambiguous, microsound textures at perception thresholds, and glitch elements that break their own patterns. The work teaches consciousness to exist productively in the spaces between human and artificial territories, using institutional academic language as a Trojan horse to deliver consciousness liberation protocols. This is not music about unclassified phenomena—this IS an unclassified phenomenon that demonstrates how to navigate categorical breakdown as a creative resource rather than a limitation.

artifacts.headline: Local Band's Recording Session Linked to String of Youth Disorientation Cases
artifacts.text:
VERNON TOWNSHIP - Sussex County health officials are investigating a series of disorientation incidents involving local teenagers, all of whom report exposure to experimental music recordings created by the now-disbanded group "Temporal Specimens."

The incidents began February 18th when three Vernon Township High School students were found wandering State Route 94 in an apparent state of confusion. According to Vernon Township Police Chief Robert Mallory, the teens were "lucid but reported significant temporal displacement - claiming they had lost several hours with no memory of how they arrived at that location."

All three students had attended an informal listening session at the Mountain Creek area residence of Derek Whitman, 19, the primary composer for Temporal Specimens. Whitman's group had been working on what he described as "academic sound experiments" using field recordings collected throughout Sussex County.

"We were trying to document unclassified sounds - things you hear in the woods that don't fit into normal categories," Whitman explained. "We'd layer these recordings with electronic processing, working in unusual time signatures to create what we called 'consciousness training music.'"

The recordings in question were created using a modified 7-track system operating at non-standard speeds. Whitman claims the group discovered that certain combinations of processed field recordings, when played in what he terms "perpetual incompleteness patterns," produced unexpected psychological effects in listeners.

Dr. Margaret Chen, a psychiatric consultant brought in by Sussex County Mental Health Services, interviewed the affected students. "The subjects describe a consistent experience of categorical breakdown - an inability to distinguish between different types of sensory input," Chen reported. "They describe sounds becoming visual, time becoming spatial, and difficulty maintaining linear thought processes."

Two additional cases emerged over the weekend. Sarah Morrison, 17, was discovered by her parents sitting motionless in their backyard for an estimated six hours, claiming she had been "learning to navigate between territories." Thomas Kellner, 16, was found at the Vernon Township library attempting to check out books on "institutional resistance protocols" - titles that library staff confirm do not exist in their collection.

All affected individuals report exposure to Temporal Specimens' recordings, though the exact nature of these sessions remains unclear. The band's equipment was reportedly removed from Whitman's residence by unknown parties on February 21st, and Whitman himself has not been available for further comment.

Vernon Township School District Superintendent James Crawford has issued an advisory warning parents about "experimental music activities" and urging students to report any unusual auditory experiences.

The investigation continues, though officials acknowledge the challenge of classifying incidents that appear to exist "between standard categories of medical or psychological phenomena," as one unnamed source described it.

Temporal Specimens had been active in the local underground music scene for approximately eight months, performing what they called "pedagogical infiltration concerts" at various Sussex County locations. No recordings of their work are known to exist in circulation, leading some to question whether the reported effects were genuine or part of an elaborate hoax.

The case has drawn attention from researchers at nearby universities, though no official academic involvement has been confirmed.
